WRITING.TEXT: Thank you!

WRITING.TITLE: A few questions about reading "The Life of Samuel Johnson"
WRITING.TEXT:
I am going to start reading it this week and I had a few questions for those who have read it. 1. Does it require a lot of background information/notes to be understood or does Boswell assume the reader knows nothing in advance? 2. Is there a better unabridged version than the Penguin Classics and Everyman's Library versions? The Penguin copy has too small print but has notes and the Everyman's has good print size but no notes (from what I can tell). 3. Any tips for reading it?
Thanks ahead of time

I read Generation of Swine and Better than Sex (his 80's and 90's book respectively). They are good and I recommend reading them with the following things in mind. At that point in his life all the alcohol and drugs were starting to get to him, he began losing faith in politics, and he had problems with Rolling Stone.
Okay I haven't read 100 Years...but I am currently reading Buddenbrooks and I highly recommend it.
This is perhaps the greatest response I have ever gotten. Thank you!

WRITING.TITLE: The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge Best Translation?
WRITING.TEXT: I want to read The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge by Rilke but there are so many translations that and no good articles (besides one comparing Mitchell's and Pike's translations). I am wondering if anyone has read the new translations (Michael Hulse- Penguin Classics and Robert Vilain- Oxford World Classics) or the old ones (Mitchell- Vintage and Pike- Dalkey Archive) and can tell me which one is best. All I have heard is that Pike's is more accurate to the German but Mitchell's is more readable. Thanks ahead of time

WRITING.TITLE: The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge Best Translation?
WRITING.TEXT: I want to read The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge by Rilke but there are so many translations that and no good articles (besides one comparing Mitchell's and Pike's translations). I am wondering if anyone has read the new translations (Michael Hulse- Penguin Classics and Robert Vilain- Oxford World Classics) or the old ones (Mitchell- Vintage and Pike- Dalkey Archive) and can tell me which one is best. All I have heard is that Pike's is more accurate to the German but Mitchell's is more readable. Thanks ahead of time
It's a great introduction. It makes Heidegger and Husserl somewhat readable. The historical context for existentialism is key to understanding the works.

WRITING.TITLE: Pevear and Volokhonsky Discussion
WRITING.TEXT: I am currently reading P+V's The Brothers Karamazov. I am finding it a little daunting not so much because of the subject matter but more of the translation. The language seems beautiful in some parts and awkward in others. I have been reading a few subreddit posts about P+V and people seem to be split over them. Are they good translators? I know that is a vague question because translations are judged by accuracy to the original language, readability, etc. But I am curious if anyone else feels this way about them. Side Question: Are their translations of The Idiot and The Demons good?

Kerouac didn't have a driver's license when he was on the "On the Road" journey. So he literally and figuratively was in the passenger's seat for the entire journey. At the end, he kinda realizes that he needs to take the wheel.

I think Sal Paradise (Kerouac) isn't giving into the system but realizing that he doesn't need Neal Cassady (i forget his name in the book) to have adventures. Cassady isn't exactly the best guide (he is kinda an asshole in the book- and was in real life too). Cassady prompts the want to journey in Sal but Sal needs to experience the world on his own.

I haven't seen the movie but I have read the story. The story offers both an argument for determinism and free will when it comes to time. The aliens think in a way in which they know everything that will happen (maybe a nonlinear look at time). While the humans think in a linear way of looking at time. I guess you could say the aliens are determinists. But the story is more about how you think about life. It asks the question is it better to know what will happen in the future or rather to let time take its course and let the answers come gradually. If you think that life is determined than you might not act out of line. But if you believe in free will exists then you think you are free and there is no scripted version of life.

"I know myself but that is all"- from the end of TSOP. I still think about that quote a lot. I was reading TBAD when I visited Fitzgerald's grave. It is a bit boring compared to his other books. As I have said in another fitzgerald post, he is better to read in publication order. You can better see his growth as a writer if you read in order. Also the books are largely autobiographical so they are a nice timeline in his and Zelda's life.

With Non-fiction, if it is a book with an argument (like a philosophy treatise) then I do a lot of research on the book and its author before jumping in. I also take notes while reading. A side note on philosophy- it is better to start from the beginning (Plato and Aristotle) before trying to read the new guys. Often the new guys reference works from the past. If it is a general nonfiction book then I usually just read it normally.

I would consider leftists and socialists "liberal". He wasn't an authoritarian socialist but rather a more libertarian socialist . A lot of people do not realize there are distinctions between socialists.

I wouldn't say it is objective. But I would say it is a good history book. Zinn wanted to give the other side of American History that gets largely ignored in history classes. Yes, it is liberal. But people need to remember that the history we learn is very narrow. We learn about the "winners". For those who think he is anti-american, citizens have a right to address the problems of the nation and its history.

I think the big lessons are (in no specific order) 1. You need to listen to both sides of a debate before picking a side. Even when you pick a side you need to not be dogmatic. 2. Pay attention to current events and don't think you are protected from everything because you are financially secure. 3. Time doesn't care about you. It continues on whether you like it or not. 4. Death is inevitable and sometimes it takes you almost dying (or being sick)to really appreciate life. Also one thing I liked was that Mann didn't pick a side when it comes to whether you should care more about the material world or the spiritual world- you have to make your own decision.

It is my favorite Fitzgerald novel. It isn't like Gatsby. It is a little like The Beautiful and Damned. It is a bildungsroman. I think reading TSOP will make you want to try The Beautiful and Damned again. I feel like Fitzgerald's novels because they are so autobiographical that you need to read them in order of publication to get a good feel for him.

WRITING.TITLE: Political Science/Political Philosophy Books
WRITING.TEXT: Hello Everyone. I am looking for some non-canon political science/political philosophy books. I know most of the main stream or canon ones (Plato, Aristotle, Huntington, etc.), but I was wondering if anyone knew any others? Thanks ahead of time
I want to start reading some pre-1900's American Classics (preferably novels, but poetry and short story collections are cool too). Any Recommendations?
Yes! It was amazing. A well written historical introduction to existentialism. I recommend you get it and take notes on the Philosophy of each person because it comes up again throughout the book.

The Illustrated Man by Ray Bradbury The Martian Chronicles by Ray Bradbury J.D. Salinger's are great (I think they should be read once and then read again after reading all 3 story books) The Things They Carried by Tim O'Brien (not exactly a short story collection, more of a novel comprised of individual stories) Will You Please be Quiet, Please? By Raymond Carver (he is a god of short stories) Flannery O'Connor is good from what I hear
I would not recommend David Foster Wallace's short stories (his essays are better) Also would not recommend Winesburg, Ohio by Sherwood Anderson (imo they are boring)
I'm pretty sure he is 1. high as hell 2. Because he is so high he is mixing up conversations he had

I would say that you are on the right track with The Aeneid and Metamorphoses. I would also add Dante's Divine Comedy and The Bible as essential prerequisites. Maybe even Chaucer's Canterbury Tales. You need to read The Odyssey and The Iliad to understand The Aeneid. And you need to read The Aeneid and The Bible to understand The Divine Comedy. You could also just dive in. The footnotes for Paradise Lost should help explain the influences.

I feel you struggle man. I have ADHD as well. Reading actually calms me down and allows me to not zone out as much. But what I would say helps (besides medicine) is reading for 30 minutes and every time you think a thought that you know you are going to zone out on, write it down and get back to reading. After the 30 minutes, look up or do what is on that list for 10 minutes. Then go back to reading. It works with the ADHD instead of against it. Hope this helps

**The Communist Manifesto, by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels**
**The Paradiso, by Dante Alighieri**

I would say it matters on the time period. I am not too well read when it comes to pre 1890's literature. I would say in no particular order- This Side of Paradise, I know why the caged bird sings, fear and loathing in LV, Either 9 stories or Catcher in the Rye. I know there are more but these ones are the ones that come immediately to mind.
I have a copy on my shelf. Is it hard to read? I have heard mixed opinions.

WRITING.TITLE: Science Fiction Classics- Asimov, Heinlein, etc
WRITING.TEXT: I'm looking for some science fiction recommendations. I'd prefer classics that maybe aren't too hard to read. I'm interested in Asimov, Heinlein, Clarke, Dick, but also open to others. disclaimer- I have barely read any sci fi. thanks ahead of time

I think you should definitely get some framed pictures or busts of writers, philosophers, etc. Another good idea is to keep everything organized, alphabetized, and neat. Yes that is obvious but you'd be surprised how annoying a search through a cluttered bookstore becomes. I think deals with trade paperbacks are always wonderful. Like 3 books for $5.

I really like The Catcher in the Rye Signet Books cover because A) If I remember correctly Salinger got mad because they depicted Holden B) The quote on the front C) It's just a beautiful cover. http://www.printmag.com/wp-content/uploads/Catcher%20pk.jpg
Norwegian Wood. I haven't read his other books but I loved NW. There were times were I just wanted to hug the guy.
I've heard "Look Homeward Angel" and the following books in the "series" by Thomas Wolfe are similar. I could be wrong.
Is Neuromancer good? I have heard conflicting opinions saying 1. it is genius + well written or 2. It is clunky and annoying.

I would jump into GR but the way I like reading author's work is more like hanging out in the shallow end and then progressively getting into the deep end of a pool. I like picking up a gradual rhythm.

I love HST too and have read almost all of his published work. However, I found Hell's Angels a lot different than all his other work. It shows pre-living fast HST's writing which is kinda boring imo.

That's a beautiful story. "Consider the Lobster and Other Essays" was the book I read during the week preceding and following my Grandfather's funeral. It kept me mildly upbeat the whole time. I have also talked to a few authors such as Matthew Thomas (We are Not Ourselves), James McBride (The Color of Water), and Lord Matthew Riddley (he has his own books but Richard Dawkins and Hitchens shout him out a lot). They all are genuinely nice people. I thought they'd be pretentious but I was proven wrong.

WRITING.TEXT: I have been running around forums and discussions for the last hour trying to find advice on what order to read Pynchon following Lot 49. I am almost done with L49 and love it. I have heard that Vineland, and Inherent Vice are good next stops. But I am interested also in V and Mason Dixon. So Where should I go next? Thanks ahead of time!

I had read so many different forums and subreddit discussions about what order to read Pynchon. Most of them offer 2 paths: 1. Pre-GR, GR, then post GR 2. Post-GR then V then GR. I am so confused. So I am asking you wonderful people where I should go next (side note: my copy of Inherit Vice is at my other place so I can't read it right away; so please not recommendations of that one). Thanks ahead of time!

WRITING.TITLE: Post-Cry of Lot 49 Pynchon Help

**The Crying of Lot 49, by Thomas Pynchon**
**Purgatorio, by Dante Alighieri**
Decided to dive into postmodernist literature.

I resorted to ordering them (I choose the Penguin Classics Deluxe Editions and for the final 2 books I did the Modern Library editions) online. But then a week after they arrived my local Barnes and Noble had a complete set. And then I went to another local used bookstore and they had most of the volumes. I also would say that since they are huge volumes that many people choose not to read because of their length and "drollness" they aren't exactly the best money makers.

I recommend the 5% or 10% a day method. I follow it until I get absorbed enough in the book to where I want to read more than just 5-10%. If the book becomes boring you can go back to the original method. You feel like you are accomplishing something everyday.
I read Brief Interviews with Ugly Men and found it "eh". White Noise was kinda boring. Is Catch 22 continuously enjoyable?

WRITING.TITLE: Postmodernism Introduction Books
WRITING.TEXT: Hello. I want to start reading Postmodernist literature but I can't find a good starting point. Everyone seems to just recommend their favorite not the easiest or most accessible. Thanks ahead of time.

WRITING.TITLE: Hard Books: Which one?
WRITING.TEXT: [removed]

I actually am using BN Classics' The Divine Comedy Translation (by Longfellow) for class rn. It is not a modern translation but we found in class that it is close to the original Italian. The endnotes and footnotes are essential for that translation.

WRITING.TITLE: Barnes and Noble Classics Editions: Good or Bad?
WRITING.TEXT: I have been reading the Barnes and Noble Classics Editions of different classics for my whole life. I started getting them as Christmas presents and now buy them because they are cheaper, have wonderful introductions, footnotes, and end notes. They also are aesthetically pleasing for the cover art is usually a beautiful painting. However, I have heard noticed while searching through "the best translation" discussions that a lot of the translations offered by the BN Classic Editions are either bad translations or are from centuries ago in which the text becomes more pretentious or clunky then it really is. Another thing I've noticed is the varying print sizes. This is weirdly important to me. I like normal to large size font which some of the editions offer while others have almost microscopic fonts. My final problem with the Editions Series as a whole is that they are inconsistent with author's work (probably because of copyright and publishing rights) or just do not have some wonderful authors. I'll continue buying them for the editions of English novels and stories but I'm wary for the translated texts. So what do you guys think about the BN Classics Editions?

**The Magic Mountain, by Thomas Mann**
**The Inferno, by Dante Alighieri**
**Too Big Too Fail by Andrew Ross Sorkin**
Almost done with TMM.

WRITING.TITLE: Discussion: Short Books vs Long Books
WRITING.TEXT: Over my reading career I have found that I have a preference for reading short books. But recently I have found myself reading longer books. There are perks to each. Short books are easier to read (and re-read) in terms of time spent, often pack a lot of emotion, plot development, etc in less pages, and feel better to finish more of them. However, longer books I feel are able to expand on themes, characters, etc, they also feel like a commitment, and also can pack a lot more in their pages by their lack of brevity. So what is subreddit community what do you think? What are your preferences and why? I'm looking forward to hearing the responses.
I read Brief Interviews with Hideous Men almost a year ago and still do not know how I feel about it.
I kinda agree with this. From the majority of White Noise I read, it seemed like DeLillo was trying to show how smart he is.

The big ones that always shock people when I tell them I can't watch them because I need to read the books are Silence of the Lambs, Oil! (There Will Be Blood), most of the film noirs (Laura comes to mind), No Country for Old Men, Forrest Gump, Schindler's List (I have read the book, it is dense), The Curious Case of Benjamin Button, Shrek, and Trainspotting (watched before I realized it was a book). Before I get hate, not everyone is a book buff like all of us so people do actually get surprised when there is a lesser known book that preceded a blockbuster movie. Also there are some movie interpretations of books that people do not know exist such as Lolita (it's directed by Kubrick!).

WRITING.TITLE: Newbie needs help with postmodernism
WRITING.TEXT: This week, for some strange reason, I have become increasingly interested in postmodernist literature. I have heard the greats are Gaddis, Pynchon, Delilo, DFW, Gass, Eco, etc. I have read a bit of DFW's work (mainly his nonfiction; opinion- his nonfiction is much more interesting than his short fiction). I need help finding a starting place. Do any of you wonderful people know a good video series, lectures, or introductory books that help explain postmodernist literature? I also would love it if someone could recommend a good starting place with actual author's works. The authors I am interested in are mainly Pynchon and Gaddis (because I can not find a clear starting point for either). But I am also interested in other authors. I know the big red box staring at me is saying I can't ask for recommendations but have mercy upon me Reddit moderators. Thanks ahead of time all commenters.

**The Magic Mountain, by Thomas Mann**
**Winesburg Ohio, by Sherwood Anderson**
The Magic Mountain is captivating and a lot easier than everyone says it is.

I would say they are biased in the sense that O'Reilly and Duggard selectively chose facts. I read both Killing Kennedy and Killing Reagan and the both leave out facts that they deemed not important towards their goals with the books. They are more general overviews of the events of the people they are covering's lives. They are good reads but not necessarily the most informative books on Kennedy, Reagan, Lincoln etc.

**Swann's Way, by Marcel Proust**
**Journey to the End of the Night, by Louis-Ferdinand Celine**
Almost done with Swann's Way. I read 50 pages a day for the last week. I recommend the Lydia Davis Translation.

I agree with the Fagles translation advice. However I would recommend before reading to do a little research on The Odyssey. It is a "sequel" to the Iliad and there are a ton of references to events or characters in the Iliad. I would also recommend the Crash Course videos on The Odyssey. John Green is bae.

Up until this year I never reread a book. I felt that I understood a book enough the first time reading it, thus it would be pointless to waste the time reading it again. Then I decided to reread a few of the books I "read" for class in high school. I reread Catcher in the Rye and The Great Gatsby. Catcher in the Rye was a nice reread but because it had been 4 years since I was 15, relating to the "teen angst" was not there. I did feel the isolation feeling. The Great Gatsby was a huge disappointment. I had spent the year reading Fitzgerald's other novels. When I reread Gatsby the novel did not stand up to his other novels. It is a very overrated novel but is worth reading. I recommend everyone rereads their high school reading list. Your favorite or least favorite books may have a new effect on you the second time around.
**Chronicle of a Death Foretold, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez** I've wanted to get into Marquez for a long time and thought this short book would be a perfect introduction.
A Curious Incident of the Dog in the Nighttime by Mark Haddon is an emotional rollercoaster. It teeters between a funny novel and a depressing novel.
**The Birth of Tragedy, by Friedrich Nietzsche** It's a supplemental reading for my new English class this semester. Also I have wanted to read it for a long time.
Well . I skimmed Pale Fire in a bookstore yesterday and liked what I read.

1. Me Talk Pretty One Day by David Sedaris (actually most books by him are hysterical) 2. The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy by Douglas Adams 3. Slaughterhouse 5 by Kurt Vonnegut 4. Cat's Cradle by Kurt Vonnegut 5. The Importance of being Earnest by Oscar Wilde 6. A Walk in the Woods by Bill Bryson

WRITING.TITLE: Literary Disappointments?
WRITING.TEXT: I just finished Lolita by Nabokov 10 minutes ago. As I read the 307th and final page I felt incredibly disappointed. I was bored throughout the whole book. The plot was kinda interesting mainly because the subject matter is insane. The prose was beautiful but it felt repetitive. The puns and witticism were nice but only a few managed to make me laugh as I did while reading Pnin. The French was nice at first but got annoying as it went on. Has anyone felt this way after finishing a book (maybe one that is "rated" so highly)?

I want to start reading In Search of Lost Time by Marcel Proust. I have Swann's Way already but I am intimidated to start it. Do any of you know a good biography of Proust, introduction to his work, etc that would be good to read before reading him? Thanks ahead of time

Hardcovers last longer but paperbacks will take a beating and are easier to carry around. I personally think paperbacks are easier to read from but hardcovers look cooler on a bookshelf. In the end, it's up to what you think looks nicer. I personally think some older paperbacks have much nicer cover and spine designs (especially the Bantem Books ones that made their cover art look like an old movie poster) than the hardcovers.

WRITING.TITLE: Reading All of an Author's Work
WRITING.TEXT: Over the last year I have tried to read all the published work of some of my favorite authors. I read all of John Green's books. I am almost done with Hunter S. Thompson, Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, David Sedaris, and J.D. Salinger. I plan to finish all of Chuck Palahniuk, David Foster Wallace, Hermann Hesse, Camus, and Joyce's works. Before these lists get any longer, I am curious to see if any of you have read all of an author's work. If so, which author(s) and why?

My favorite is a tie between "Looking for Alaska" by John Green and "The Perks of Being a Wallflower" by Stephen Chbosky. I think both novels perfectly capture what it is like being a teenager and high school and the corresponding emotional roller coaster ride that is growing up. I have always felt that good young adult novels can make you feel the sublime ecstasy of being a highschooler again.

I printed out a few lists of the best books of all time/20th century/etc, compared them all, and marked which books were on multiple lists. But besides choosing from these lists, I usually just ask the nice people that work at bookstores. Most of the people that work in bookstores are well-read and can probably recommend something if you describe a type of book you want to read. The recommendations/lists on Goodreads.com also are pretty good for finding what you want to read.
**Choke, by Chuck Palahniuk**

The first book I read in my freshman year was "A Portrait of an Artist as a Young Man" by James Joyce. The ending is powerful and gave me this feeling that I, just like Stephen, was about to embark on a journey.

My old university's library used to have give away these bookmarks with "The Sea off Suruga Province from Fuji Sanjurokkei" by Ando, Hiroshige. (http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/citi/images/standard/WebLarge/WebImg_000029/79528_434478.jpg). I took about 20 of them and use them in all my books.

WRITING.TITLE: Certain Book Binding/Print Preferences?
WRITING.TEXT: I am wondering if I am alone in my certain preferences when it comes to book bindings and print types. I really like when books are the white Bantam Book binding (for example https://www.google.com/search?q=bantam+book+paperback rlz=1CAACAG_enUS691US691 espv=2 biw=1366 bih=631 source=lnms tbm=isch sa=X ved=0ahUKEwi94OXHm9HOAhUDox4KHboeDMEQ_AUIBygC#tbm=isch q=bantam+book+paperback+hesse imgrc=E7PKy8KSm02BpM%3A). I also really like it when the print is larger and there are fewer words on a page. Also the Library of America hardcover editions are amazing. So, before I embarrass myself anymore... does anyone have these preferences and if so what are they?
For #3, To Have and Have Not by Ernest Hemingway takes place in Key West and Cuba and involves a lot of sailing.

I hear Freakonomics is good. Most economics books are pretty dense and the famous ones such as Wealth of Nations by Adam Smith are outdated. Keynes and Marx are interesting in the sense that their theories still influence modern economics.
Pnin by Vladimir Nabokov. A very short and funny book from one of the greats that is often overlooked.

Whenever I read Nietzsche I read him out loud. I always find myself yelling by the end of the section. While I do not necessarily agree with everything he writes, I think his writing is full of power.
**Why I am Not a Christian and other essays on religion and related subjects, by Bertrand Russell** and **Demian, by Hermann Hesse**

I had to read it in my freshman year of high school for my English class. The whole book is an emotional roller coaster. Books do not normally make me sad but when the main character hears about what happened to Hassan, it wrecked me.

This Side of Paradise by F. Scott Fitzgerald and Steppenwolf by Hermann Hesse both changed my life. They were not my first books with both authors but they are both my favorites from each. TSOP is not a typical Fitzgerald novel but it shows his genius at such a young age. Steppenwolf blew my mind and I think about it at least once a week.

I would recommend The Stranger by Albert Camus (also all of his novels are pretty easy), Demian and Siddhartha by Hermann Hesse, Nausea by Jean-Paul Sartre, The Alchemist by Paulo Coelho, and Candide by Voltaire.
Darkness at Noon by Arthur Koestler and Brave New World by Aldous Huxley were two dystopian novels I loved. I hear The Iron Heel by Jack London is pretty good aswell.

Lending books is my favorite thing to do. I feel like I am sharing an experience with someone else. However, recently I had to adopt a new policy for my booklending. I used to lend any book I had to my friends. But after giving three copies of The Beautiful and Damned to three different girls and never having a copy for myself to read for the first time, I had to change my style. Now I only lend books that I have already read to my friends.

I read the book while going to school in DC. I agree with the mindblowing history of what DC used to be. For example, the area where his "rundown" apartment was is now an incredibly expensive area. I have read almost everything HST wrote and if you enjoy '72 then you will love The Gonzo Papers series. I just finished Better Than Sex (Gonzo Papers 4) and loved it. He talks a lot about the Clintons and gives his "interesting" opinion on Hillary. Stick with '72. It gets a little boring towards the end but the ending made me smile. It was also fitting that when I looked up from the last page, I saw the Washington Monument.
Choke by Chuck Palahniuk has by far the most aggressive beginning I have ever read.
Thanks!

A Little Life by Hanya Yanagihara. The whole book is depressing (and incredibly long, I still haven't finished it) but the chapter about Willem's disabled brother had me almost sobbing in the middle of an airport.

WRITING.TITLE: Where to start with Philosophy?
WRITING.TEXT: Over the last few months I have found myself becoming more and more interested in studying philosophy. I have run into some roadblocks of where to start. I have heard three ways of starting. 1. Start at the very beginning with the Greek Philosophers (i.e. Plato, Aristotle). 2. Start with the most accessible/most readable philosophy books. 3. Start with the most interesting philosophy books. I am wondering which of these paths I should follow. I am also curious as to which books are the easiest to start out with. Thank you for your suggestions ahead of time.
What would you say are the most accessible Greek philosophy books to start with?
By far one of the greatest plays I have ever read. I hear the stage adaptation was quite good.
I read that earlier in the summer. A lot of Kafka's stories are a lot funnier than people give him credit for.

**White Noise, by Don DeLillo** I was told it was a great book and also a great introduction into postmodernism. I started reading it months ago but had to return it to my university's library before I could finish it.

WRITING.TITLE: Where to start with Philosophy?
WRITING.TEXT: [removed]

I will admit being an atheist used to make me sad. For most of my life I selfishly believed in an afterlife that would preserve my mind after death. Even when I was an agnostic, I still held onto this notion of the afterlife. But after doing some deep thinking and reading some books on atheism (notably "The God Delusion" and "God is not Great") I realized that the afterlife is a myth but that is not exactly as bad a thing as I thought it would be. I feel now that I have been lucky enough to be born and given a chance to experience life. While the ending is not pleasant, I know every moment leading up to it I will celebrating and enjoying life. Sometimes the end makes you enjoy the journey more.
Steppenwolf is full of breath taking lines. The one that I always loved (and have made my Instagram bio quote) is "Eternity is a mere moment, just long enough for a joke".

During my freshman year of college I re-read The Great Gatsby and The Catcher in the Rye. I have a good memory so I thought I was not going to enjoy them as well as I did when I was a sophomore in high school reading them. Upon re-reading I was shocked by how "different" they were from how I remembered them. I think everyone has this revelation of how much they have grown up when they re-do something they did years ago. Back to the books. The Great Gatsby fell in comparison to the other Fitzgerald novels I had read earlier in the year (namely This Side of Paradise). The Catcher in the Rye was interesting because its feelings of social isolation were still there but its general feel did not strike me as much as it used to.
